question: Its scientific name is Sedum morganianum.
The color of the leaves of this plant is dark green and can often include red and pink toward the tips of the leaves.
A succulent plant that originates from Madagascar and has soft, fuzzy leaves that looks a bit like fur.
It doesn’t require much pruning and is considered endangered in the wild.
It is a branching succulent that forms large rosettes of variegated spoon-shaped leaves at the tip of the branches.
A succulent that tends to be clustered at the ends of the branch rather than spaced evenly among them.
This plant was created as a hybrid between Senecio rowleyanus and Senecio articulatus.
It is a popular clump-forming succulent with chubby, pale blue-green to bluish-purple leaves arranged in a rosette at the tips of short stems.
The most favorable temperature for this succulent is 60 to 80 degrees Fahrenheit.
You will only need to repot this plant during spring when the existing pot is too small for it to fit anymore, as it begins to actually bloom when the temperature drops down during the winter.
It has a scientific name of Parodia magnifica and it originates from South America
It is an ideal plant for beginners’ gardeners and it is not a fast-growing plant as it will do just fine in the same pot for several years.
It has a thick, dark green leaves with bumps of white tubercles on the outer surface that are clustered together, hence giving its name.
Its leaves are reflective that helps minimize the risk of the plant overheating and produce fuzzy flowers when grown in the wild.
It can live for a very long time and grow into small trees or shrubs up to 5 feet tall.
